posts.post_content: So , I recently created a[Momir Vig, Simic Visionary](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Momir Vig, Simic Visionary) EDH deck and decided to throw this guy in it due to the multiple ETB's it had and the fact 6 cmc isn't much in this format. Little did I know how much Deadeye was going to impact my deck, especially if Momir is out. [Eternal Witness](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Eternal Witness) on this dude with a [Turnabout](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Turnabout) in hand is easy infinite mana, letting you cast creatures to tutor up whatever is needed, like [Prime Speaker Zegana](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prime Speaker Zegana) filling your hand, putting the Momir trigger first, snagging [Acidic Slime](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Acidic Slime). I could point out all the other triggers that everyone else had, but my main point is: this is exactly what a good magic card is all about; Awesome use of a set mechanic, awesome art, flexible in multiple formats and a cmc that fits the package.
posts.html:
So , I recently created aMomir Vig, Simic Visionary EDH deck and decided to throw this guy in it due to the multiple ETB's it had and the fact 6 cmc isn't much in this format. Little did I know how much Deadeye was going to impact my deck, especially if Momir is out. Eternal Witness on this dude with a Turnabout in hand is easy infinite mana, letting you cast creatures to tutor up whatever is needed, like Prime Speaker Zegana filling your hand, putting the Momir trigger first, snagging Acidic Slime. I could point out all the other triggers that everyone else had, but my main point is: this is exactly what a good magic card is all about; Awesome use of a set mechanic, awesome art, flexible in multiple formats and a cmc that fits the package.

posts.post_content:
@steev, no, that's not correct. From the rules:  
702.92a. Soulbond is a keyword that represents two triggered abilities. "Soulbond" means "When this creature enters the battlefield, if you control both this creature and another creature and both are unpaired, you may pair this creature with another unpaired creature you control for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control" and "Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, if you control both that creature and this one and both are unpaired, you may pair that creature with this creature for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control."  
  
So whenever either this or the once-paired creature flickers back in, you can re-pair or pair with another creature.  
  
What that ruling is saying is that when either creature enters the exile zone, it loses the ability and won't get it back unless a pair takes place. It seems like a confusing ruling - it would make sens... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
@steev, no, that's not correct. From the rules:
702.92a. Soulbond is a keyword that represents two triggered abilities. "Soulbond" means "When this creature enters the battlefield, if you control both this creature and another creature and both are unpaired, you may pair this creature with another unpaired creature you control for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control" and "Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, if you control both that creature and this one and both are unpaired, you may pair that creature with this creature for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control."

So whenever either this or the once-paired creature flickers back in, you can re-pair or pair with another creature.

What that ruling is saying is that when either creature enters the exile zone, it loses the ability and won't get it back unless a pair takes place. It seems like a confusing ruling - it would make sens... (see all)

posts.post_content:
Recently playing him in a blue green deck. With geralf's mindcrusher and acidic ooze. When it says "1U: mill for five cards" or "1u: destroy target artifact, enchantment or land", things are looking good. :)  
  
Still, this guy is balanced. He can't escape from mass removal, unlike cards that get exiled until end of turn, instead of returning immediately. And you can't exile both this and the soulbounded card at once.

posts.post_content:
Things to Do with Dead-Eye  
  
Draw Cards = [Prime Speaker Zegana](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prime Speaker Zegana)  
Exile Enemy Creatures = [Duplicant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Duplicant) / [Phyrexian Ingester](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Ingester)  
Gain Life + Tokens = [Thragtusk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thragtusk)  
Destroy Land = [Acidic Slime](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Acidic Slime)  
Destroy Planeswalkers = [Sylvan Primordial](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sylvan Primordial)  
Counter Spells =[Mystic Snake](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mystic Snake)  
Tap out Enemy During their turn = [Mistbind Clique](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mistbind Clique)  
Infinite Mana = [Palinchron](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Palinchron) / [Great Whale](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Great Whale)  
Control All Permanents + Infinite Mana = [Zealous con](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Zealous con) + [Gilded Lotus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gilded Lotus)  
  
And he's tough to get rid of himself with a 5/5 Body and able to blink from target removal. 5/5 fun Flavor and extremely Combo Friendly

Posted By: BryceCarmony (20/08/2013 5:59:10 PM)

posts.post_content:
I run him in EDH in my mono-blue deck. The deck is control and combo, and [Deadeye Navigator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deadeye Navigator) is the broken heart and soul of the combos.  
  
He combos with [Great Whale](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Great Whale) or [Palinchron](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Palinchron) for Infinite mana.  
  
Or [Venser, Shaper Savant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Venser, Shaper Savant) (my general) to counter every spell, or make it so they have no lands.  
  
Or [Mulldrifter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mulldrifter) to draw your deck.  
  
Or [Mnemonic Wall](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mnemonic Wall) or [Archaeomancer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Archaeomancer) to get back your spells from your graveyard.  
  
And that's just the simple combos. Just like I would run [Conjurer's Closet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Conjurer's Closet) in every EDH deck, I would run [Deadeye Navigator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deadeye Navigator) in every EDH deck that runs blue. The core of that format is enter the battlefield effects, and repeating those virtually at will benefit you more than you can imagine until you live it.  
  
5/5
posts.html:

He combos with Great Whale or Palinchron for Infinite mana.

Or Venser, Shaper Savant (my general) to counter every spell, or make it so they have no lands.

Or Mulldrifter to draw your deck.

Or Mnemonic Wall or Archaeomancer to get back your spells from your graveyard.

And that's just the simple combos. Just like I would run Conjurer's Closet in every EDH deck, I would run Deadeye Navigator in every EDH deck that runs blue. The core of that format is enter the battlefield effects, and repeating those virtually at will benefit you more than you can imagine until you live it.

5/5

posts.post_content:
@SAUS3: This card is so much more irritating than Kiki-Jiki that it's incredible you'd even make the comparison. KJ only gets one activation per turn, requires heavy investment into *red*, the least powerful color EDH (while this thing is blue, the best one), is very hard to kill, and can blink legendary creatures like [Prime Speaker Zegana](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prime Speaker Zegana).  
  
@Lifegainwithbite: He was specifically talking about EDH, so your point about modern is pretty moot. Sure, KJ can win the game on the spot with some dudes, but so can [Worldgorger Dragon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Worldgorger Dragon), which I'm pretty sure we can agree isn't terribly useful when you aren't comboing off with it. In a vacuum, Deadeye is much more powerful than KJ.
posts.html:

KJ only gets one activation per turn, requires heavy investment into red, the least powerful color EDH (while this thing is blue, the best one), is very hard to kill, and can blink legendary creatures like Prime Speaker Zegana.

posts.post_content:
Oh my, the combos. I have a deck built around this guy, [Cloudshift](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cloudshift), and [Ghostly Flicker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ghostly Flicker). Heres some of the pairings I've managed:  
  
[Thragtusk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thragtusk): Life and beasts. Not much to say here.  
[Acidic Slime](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Acidic Slime): Land/friendship destruction  
[Sphinx of Uthuun](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sphinx of Uthuun): Card advantage. ALL the card advantage.  
[Mist Raven](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mist Raven): Nah, [Lightning Mauler](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lightning Mauler), I know your eager, but you're just gonna have to be patient.  
[Lavinia of the Tenth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lavinia of the Tenth): Shuts down aggro  
[Gatecreeper Vine](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gatecreeper Vine)/[Borderland Ranger](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Borderland Ranger): Never miss a land drop again  
[Sunblast Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sunblast Angel): Attack me, I dare you.  
[Fiend Hunter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fiend Hunter): Stack abuse --> Exile everything.  
  
And that's just my deck. More fun to be had with evolve triggers, beefing up [Champion of Lambholt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Champion of Lambholt), evading targeted removal, [Trostani's Summoner/au](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Trostani's Summoner/au)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
